input.name: title
input.label: Title
input.help-text: Optionally add a title to the form.

input.name: inputs
input.label: Add input fields
input.help-text: Add the input fields to display in your form. These must be created before they can be added, but you can save the form and return to add them later.

input.name: actionUrl
input.label: URL to submit form to
input.help-text: This is used as the "action" attribute on the form, and refers to where the form is sent when submitted. You can leave this empty unless you want to submit to a a third-party application or want to handle the response in a special way. If empty, the form is submitted to the current page, and the default handler saves the response to the folder specified. When the "Ajax submit" is checked, only the form data is sent to the target URL, while the user remains on the current page.

input.name: responseFolder
input.label: Folder to store responses
input.help-text: Select where to store response content. If no folder is selected, the responses will be stored as child elements of the current page.

input.name: response
input.label: Response message
input.help-text: Add a response to show to the user when the form has been submitted. This is only used when "Ajax submit" is enabled.

input.name: submitText
input.label: Submit button-text
input.help-text: Customize the text of the select button if you want. Defaults to "Submit".

input.name: method
input.label: Submit method
input.help-text: "GET" should be used for example in searches, where the input parameters define what the user views. "POST" should be used when changing data or in most cases when submitting a form.

input.name: useAjax
input.label: Ajax submit
input.help-text: Only un-check when the user should be sent to the target page upon submitting the form. An example of when this is useful is a search form, where the user should arrive at a result-page.

input.name: style
input.label: Style
input.help-text: Select which styling to apply. If "Browser default" is used, no style sheet is loaded for the form application, and you have full control over the form styling. "Twitter Bootstrap" currently uses v.3.3.5. "XP Formbuilder" is an extra example.
